SENT.plain: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES: Cyclosporine A (CsA) has become one of the leading agents for the treatment of pure red cell aplasia (PRCA)

However, further studies are necessary to determine the relapse-free survival (RFS) and overall survival (OS) of patients treated with this drug, the minimum duration of therapy for induction of remission, and whether or not there is need for maintenance treatment
DESIGN AND METHODS: We conducted a nationwide survey in Japan
From a total of 185 patients (with 73 primary idiopathic PRCA and 112 with secondary PRCA), we evaluated 62 patients with primary idiopathic PRCA for this report
RESULTS: The remission induction therapy for these patients included CsA (n=31), corticosteroids (CS) (n=20) or other drugs (n=11)
CsA and CS produced remissions in 23 (74%) and 12 (60%) patients, respectively
The salvage treatment produced remissions in 58 patients (94%)
Forty-one and 15 patients were maintained on CsA+/-CS (CsA-containing group) or CS alone (CS group), respectively
The median RFS in the CsA-containing group was 103 months, longer than that seen in the CS group (33 months) (p<0.01)

Of 14 patients whose CsA was discontinued, 12 patients (86%) relapsed after a median of 3 months (range 1.5 to 40 months), while only 3 of 27 patients (11%) relapsed during CsA-containing maintenance therapy
Thus, the discontinuance of maintenance therapy was strongly correlated with relapse (p<0.001)
Four patients in the CsA-containing group died; however, the OS of this group was not significantly different from that of the CS-groups (p=0.104)
INTERPRETATION AND CONCLUSIONS: CsA-containing regimens sustain prolonged RFS more effectively than CS in primary idiopathic PRCA and seem to be important to prevent relapse
